Classes & Value Types

Emojicode features two kind of types that feature object-orientation: Classes and Value Types.

Defining a Class

The syntax to define a class is

ğŸ‡ class [superclass] ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰
superclass âŸ¶ type-identifier
class âŸ¶ type

If you omit superclass the class wonâ€™t have a superclass.

As for example the code below defines a ğŸŸ class, that has no superclass.

ğŸ‡ ğŸŸ ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰

We can now subclass this ğŸŸ class and declare a ğŸ¡ class that represents a blowfish â€“ a more concrete type of fish:

ğŸ‡ ğŸ¡ ğŸŸ ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰

Defining a Value Type

The syntax to define a value type is the following:

ğŸ•Š value-type ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰
value-type âŸ¶ type-identifier
Hint

The defined types are immediately available in the namespaces provided in value-type or class. Please see Types to gain a deeper understanding of namespaces and their use in declarations.

Classes versus Value Types

There are significant difference betweeen classes and value types:

  • Instances of classes are always allocated on the heap and are passed by reference. Instances of value types are, as their name suggests, passed by value.

  • Classes feature inheritance while value types donâ€™t.

Instance Variables

To store information in your type instances, instance variables are used. The ğŸ° syntax is used to declare an instance variable.

The example below defines a ğŸŸ class with instance variables.

ğŸ‡ ğŸŸ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ° age ğŸš‚
  ğŸ° speedInM/s ğŸš€
  ğŸ° name ğŸ¬ğŸ”¡  ğŸ‘´ Fish kept in aquariums often have names
ğŸ‰

When a type is instantiated a scope is created in which the instance variables live. This scope is always available in methods and initializers.

Instance variables are private to the instance and cannot be accessed from outside. If you want to allow modification or access of an instance variable from outside a class or value type you have to write getters and setters. Note that instance variables are also kept private from subclasses.

Initializers

Initializers are responsible to prepare an instance for use and are called to instantiate a type, that is gaining an instance of the given type.

The syntax to define an initializer is:

ğŸˆ name [init-parameters] ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰
init-parameters âŸ¶ init-parameter | init-parameter init-parameters
init-parameter âŸ¶ [ğŸ¼] variable type

In an initializer all instance variables must be initialized. (Remember that variables of an optional type are automatically initialized to Nothingness, which is also true for instance variables.)

Furthermore, if youâ€™re initializing a class instance whose class has a superclass you must call an initializer of the superclass . The ğŸ keyword is used to call a superinitializer:

ğŸ superinitializer [arguments]

By enforcing these rules, Emojicode can guarantee that any instance of any type is always fully initialized when obtained from the intializer.

The following example is an initializer for the ğŸŸ class:

ğŸˆ ğŸ ageGiven ğŸš‚ nameGiven ğŸ¬ğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ® age ageGiven
  ğŸ® name nameGiven
  ğŸ® speedInM/s 0
ğŸ‰

This initializer initializes all variables to appropriate values. age and name were initialized to values passed by arguments. speedInM/s was set to a default value.

Value type initializers work quite similarly, with one big difference: In contrast to class initializers they return a value. This will change in a further version of Emojicode.

Initializing Instance Variables from Arguments

Because itâ€™s so common that instance variables are initialized from arguments, thereâ€™s a shortcut to this: ğŸ¼. ğŸ¼ can be used in front of the variable name of an argument and then automatically copies the value passed into the instance variable with the same name.

The example above improved with ğŸ¼:

ğŸˆ ğŸ ğŸ¼ age ğŸš‚ ğŸ¼ name ğŸ¬ğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ® speedInM/s 0
ğŸ‰

Instantiation

To get an instance of a class or value type, you must instantiate it. ğŸ”· is used for instantiation.

Its syntax is:

ğŸ”· type initializer [arguments]

initializer must be the name of the initializer you want to use. Naturally, you need to provide the correct number of appropriate arguments.

To get a ğŸŸ instance for example, you would use:

ğŸ”·ğŸŸğŸ 2 ğŸ”¤BillyğŸ”¤

Nothingness Initializers

There are some cases where a initializer can fail. For instance, an initializer that should open a file, will fail if the file does not exist.

These kind of initializers are called Nothingness Initializers and they can return, as their name suggests, nothingness.

To declare a Nothingness Initializer, the ğŸ¬ attribute is used. Example:

ğŸŒ® Tries to lure a fish at the given age with pizza. ğŸŒ®
ğŸ¬ ğŸˆ ğŸ• age. ğŸš‚ ğŸ‡
  ğŸŠ â—€ï¸ age. 1 ğŸ‡
    ğŸ‘´ You canâ€™t lure fish younger than one year with pizza
    ğŸ âš¡ï¸
  ğŸ‰
  ğŸ® age age.
  ğŸ‘´ ...
ğŸ‰

As you can see in the above example, you use ğŸ in combination with âš¡ï¸ to return nothingness. Using such an initializer with ğŸ”· naturally gives you an optional.

Methods

Methods are functionality bound to a specific type: a class or value type.

The syntax to define a method is:

ğŸ– method-emoji [parameters] [return-type] ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰
parameters âŸ¶ parameter | parameter parameters
parameter âŸ¶ variable type
return-type âŸ¶ â¡ï¸ type

Hereâ€™s an example from the ğŸŸ class:

ğŸŒ® Swim the given distance within one hour. ğŸŒ®
ğŸ– ğŸŠ distanceInMeters ğŸš€ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ® speedInM/s â— distanceInMeters 3600
ğŸ‰

Every methods return a value. As you can see in the syntax definition, you can declare return types. If no return type was declared the return type defaults to âœ¨. ğŸ is used to explicitly return a value:

ğŸ value

Letâ€™s look at another example from the ğŸŸ class that uses ğŸ:

ğŸŒ® Determines whether this fish should retire. ğŸŒ®
ğŸ– ğŸ‘¨ â¡ï¸ ğŸ‘Œ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ â–¶ï¸ age 4
ğŸ‰

You canâ€™t use the names of language statements as method names since you wonâ€™t be able to call the method if you do so. You can find a list of these reserved emojis at the end of this chapter.

Calling Methods

The syntax to call a method is special:

method-emoji value [arguments]

method-emoji is the name of the method you wish to call. value is the instance whose method should be called. Of course all arguments must be provided as required.

Hint

This means that any emoji that is not used with a language construct is a method call!

Example:

ğŸ¦ michaelTheFish ğŸ”·ğŸŸğŸ 3 ğŸ”¤MichaelğŸ”¤
ğŸŠ michaelTheFish 300
ğŸŠ ğŸ‘¨ michaelTheFish ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¤Michael will retire!ğŸ”¤
ğŸ‰

This Context

You often will want to get the value on which the method was called, this is the object or the value. ğŸ• is your friend here:

ğŸ•

The ğŸ• returns the current value, whose method or initializer is being called.

Here, for instance, a method of ğŸŸ is shown, which calls another method to determine whether the fish on which the method was called should retire or can sign a new contract of employment:

ğŸŒ® Signs a new contract of employment. ğŸŒ®
ğŸ– ğŸ–Š ğŸ‡
  ğŸŠ ğŸ‘¨ ğŸ• ğŸ‡
    ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¤Sorry, Iâ€™d prefer to retire.ğŸ”¤
  ğŸ‰
  ğŸ“ ğŸ‡
    ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¤I hope theyâ€™ll pay me twice as much.ğŸ”¤
  ğŸ‰
ğŸ‰

Note that in an initializer, you canâ€™t use ğŸ• before the object is fully initialized, that is before all instance variables were set and the superinitializer was called. If this was allowed, you could call methods on the instance which might access instance variable that had not been initialized yet.

Type Methods

Itâ€™s possible to define type methods which are called on the type rather than on an instance of the type.

Type methods are defined like normal methods but with the ğŸ‡ attribute. As for example:

ğŸ‡ ğŸ• ğŸ‡
  ğŸŒ® Returns the available pizzas. ğŸŒ®
  ğŸ‡ğŸ– ğŸ“œ â¡ï¸ ğŸ¨ğŸšğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡
    ğŸ ğŸ¨ ğŸ”¤MargheritağŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤TonnoğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤Quattro FormaggiğŸ”¤ ğŸ†
  ğŸ‰
ğŸ‰

Since type methods donâ€™t execute in an object context the use of ğŸ• is illegal. Type methods are also inherited by subclasses.

Calling Type Methods

The syntax to call a type method is:

ğŸ© method-emoji type [arguments]

Example:

ğŸ© ğŸ“œ ğŸ•

This calls the type method ğŸ“œ on the class ğŸ•, which we just defined above.

Access Modifiers

Access Modifiers describe from which context a method, class method or initializer can be called. There are three access modifiers, which can be applied to methods, initializers, and class methods.

  • ğŸ”“: The method, initializer, or class method can be accessed from everywhere.
  • ğŸ”’: The method, initializer, or class method may only be accessed within the class it was defined.
  • ğŸ”: The method, initializer, or class method may only be accessed within the class it was defined or within a class that inherits from that class.

Object Address Compare

ğŸ˜œ can be used to determine whether two objects have the same memory address and are thus really the same object. This isnâ€™t an equality check: Two objects might represents the same value but they are still two different object not sharing the same memory location. To determine equality use ğŸ˜› if available.

ğŸ˜œ object object
object âŸ¶ value

ğŸ˜œ returns true if both objects are references to the same memory location.

object must be a ğŸ”µ.
